Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Support for the 2015 Annual Meeting of the Society for Mathematical Psychology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for student participation at the 2015 Annual Meeting of the Society for Mathematical Psychology, to be to be held in Newport Beach, CA in July 2015. The annual meeting will advance discovery and understanding of theoretical problems in psychology and the social sciences. It will create an environment in which mathematically oriented social scientists can grow and flourish. It will promote training and learning of new models and methods for analyzing behavioral data and make possible the broad dissemination of new findings important in all areas of psychology, as well as economics, political science, sociology, and anthropology. Support for student travel will allow the organizers to involve more individuals from underrepresented groups.

Mathematical psychology is interdisciplinary by nature, bringing together social scientists, statisticians, mathematicians, and computer scientists to work on problems critical to behavioral and cognitive scientists. The 2015 annual meeting will include three symposia on new developments that have not been featured at recent meetings: (1) Dynamics of adaptive rationality; (2) Systems factorial technology; and (3) New developments in the analysis and modeling of naturally occurring data sets. The annual meeting also will include a half-day professional development symposium organized by the Women of Mathematical Psychology and a post-conference networking event with potential industrial partners.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant provided partial support for the 48th Annual Meeting of the Society for Mathematical Psychology, held in Newport Beach, CA, from July 17 through July 21, 2015. Over 150 scientists from across the world attended, and most presented papers on topics using mathematical and computational methods in multiple fields in psychology. The conference included symposia on the topics of "Dynamics of Adaptive Rationality," "Systems Factorial Technology Through the Ages," and New Developments in the Analysis and Modeling of Naturally Occurring Data Sets."

Also featured were plenary addresses given by Barbara Dosher (UC Irvine), Ralph Hertwig (Max Plank Institute), and Joachim Vandekerckhove (UC Irvine).  Christopher Donkin and Brandon Turner were honored with the 2015 William K. Estes Early Career Award. In addition, there were two preconference workshops. One was on "Teaching Bayesian Statistics with JASP" (by E.J. Wagenmakers). The second was a symposium on "Demystifying and Mastering the Peer Review Process," organized by the Women of Mathematical Psychology. There was also a post-conference session on "Industrial Applications of Mathematical Psychology" in which students and researchers gave prepared business pitches to a jury of venture capitalists.

The majority of the project award was provided to students to offset some expenses to attend the conference (registration cost) in order to encourage greater student involvement. Additional information about the Society can be found at http://www.mathpsych.org/.
